_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Prior to 2006, Apio Cooling used ammonia as part of a shared ammonia refrigeration system with one other facility  Per the LEPC, one Risk Management Plan was prepared for both facilities.  In 2006, Apio Cooling developed their own independent refrigeration system.  This submittal represents Apio Cooling as an independent, stand-alone ammonia refrigeration process.

A. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The facilities located in Guadalupe, California, utilize refrigeration for ice making and cold storage.

Senior management at the facilities are not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities.  Senior management administer the safety and environmental policies and programs.  These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

Apio Cooling has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the Santa Barbara County Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Apio Cooling to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.

A majority of the ammonia equipment is located inside the engine room.  The system is a closed loop refrigeration system similar to a residential refrigerator.  There are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia.

B. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  The system has a low pressure or low side, where the refrigerant absorbs heat as it evaporates, and a high pressure or high side, where the refrigerant vapor gives off heat as it is condensed back into a liquid.  (In operat

ion the system basically moves heat from the low side to the high side.)  Refrigeration is maintained by isolating the low side in some form of insulated enclosure where goods are chilled or frozen.  

Ammonia is the regulated substance of concern.  There is approximately 24,000 pounds of ammonia in this single process.

C.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Apio Cooling ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. 

The Process Safety Management program ensures that all security and safety procedures are addressed.  Staff are trained in operation, maintenance and emergency procedures related to the operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  All refrigeration equipment and ammonia vessels are equipped with automatic pressure safety relief devices to prevent pressure build-up beyond safe equipment operation levels.  A preventative maintenance program assures that equipment is maintained and serviced on a regular schedule and that worn, ageing, or defective components are replaced as required to maintain equipment in good operating condition.  Controls and safety devices are tested regularly to ensure proper operation.

D.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The five year accident history investigation (September 2001 to September 2006) revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release.  

E.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Apio Cooling's Emergency Response Plan was designed to ensure a safe and healthful working environment.  The policy at Apio Cooling is to identify and correct unsafe conditions and work practices before an incident can occur.  The Emergency Response Plan outlines the company safety policy, responsibilities, accident investigation, and proper sa

fety training procedures required to provide a safe work place.  

Apio Cooling's Emergency Response Plan is outlined in the PSM/RMP documentation and focuses on responding to ammonia releases.

Response Organization and Notification Procedures 
In the event of an accident, the operator should immediately notify his supervisor.  During the first few moments of the event, the witness should assess the situation as follows:

1) How severe is the problem?
2) Is there any personnel in danger?
3) What is running at the time?
4) Where is the leak source?
5) What can be done about the leak?
6) Has the hazard communication process been initiated?

If the operator was able to extinguish the emergency, then the accident investigator should be notified.  The accident investigator then proceeds to consider several questions as to the incidents surrounding the emergency.  The questions are numerous and include finding out key elements as to the occurrence of the accident.  Some key questions include the following:  

1) Who was involved?  
2) What was the accident? 
3) When did it occur? 
4) Why did the operator react the way he did? 
5) Where did the accident occur? How did he get injured? 
6) How could this be avoided in the future?

All ammonia leaks, regardless of size, are reported to the Santa Barbara County Fire Department.  Finally, the refrigeration service organization is notified to assist in putting the plant back on-line following an ammonia release.

Evacuation Routes and Procedures
In the event of an emergency requiring evacuation, personnel will be instructed to vacate the premises to the designated assembly area.  This is upwind of the release and typically at the northwest corner of the facility.  

Mitigation Measures
A group response team will be established to assess the situation and be available to assist the Fire Department.  All personnel are required to evacuate the facility in the event of an ammonia release.  Certain trained personnel are authorized t

o shut down the ammonia refrigeration system while exiting the area; however, the installation of ammonia sensors is the primary mitigation measure for shutting down the system.

F.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Apio Cooling is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.  Continue to train all employees in PSM/RMP/CalARP and safety programs.

2.  Continue to have employee involvement in updating and refining PSM/RMP/CalARP and the facility's safety programs.

3.  Continue employee involvement through the Employee Participation program.

4.  Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
